column4: anybody got a few minutes for some advice on some backup issue type questions?
i.e. backup the entire drive but it's encrypted
do you want the backups encrypted too?
most definitely...what'd be the point backing up data and leaving it unencrypted? :)
somehow i figure doing a dd if=/dev/sda of=drive.img type of command won't get me what i want since the drive is encrypted
well, it would work -- but the resulting file wouldn't be encrypted (i should think so)
ya...thus my "problem"
you could do something like .  dd id=/dev/sda | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in - -out encrypted.enc
that could work...the thought i was wondering is that if i boot off a live cd and dd the drive in that manner would the resulting image be useful since the drive wasn't opened with luks?
well, im not sure, i would presume that it wouldn't make sense

yeah i'm not sure either...i was leaning towards opening the drive with luks and thus gaining access then backing up the data...a 1:1 copy a la cpio would be nice since a ton of data is video which doesn't lend well to compression unlike the rest of the filesystem
well, if you can mount your luks volume like that, then sure .. anything works
a tarball that got encrypted would be ideal but a ton of wasted processing cycles would take place trying to compress multimedia files (which is ~90% of the drive)
you don't need to compress the tarball
or rather, you don't have to..
this is true...old sysadmin habit :)
looks like i came up with a workable solution: duplicity will allow me to hobble together enough of what i need to accomplish
is that duplicity - a name of an app or do you mean a mirrored volume?
name of an app
ahh, cool
straight up command line driven, highly configurable...roll your own type of solution :)
will keep that at the back of my brain if i ever find out rsync to be incapable :)
ya i'd rsync but it wouldn't work well for my scenario
